Workflow

Functions:

faker_api_workflow(desired_number_of_rows[, ...])

This is a generic workflow to get data from the API: https://fakerapi.it/api/v1/ and ingest into SQLite database that will be created in your work directory.
faker_api_workflow.faker_api_workflow(desired_number_of_rows: int, columns_to_mask_by_len: List = ['firstname', 'lastname', 'address.buildingNumber'], unwanted_columns: List = ['address.id', 'id'], if_exists: str = 'append', database_str: str = 'taxfix-challenge', table_str: str = 'FAKER_API')[source]

This is a generic workflow to get data from the API: https://fakerapi.it/api/v1/ and ingest into SQLite database that will be created in your work directory. The data will be transformed using some functions that you can find in the package “faker”.

Parameters

  • desired_number_of_rows (int) – The number of rows that you want to request

  • columns_to_mask_by_len (List, optional) – List of columns that you want to use MaskColumn().bylen Default: [‘firstname’,’lastname’,’address.buildingNumber’]

  • unwanted_columns (List, optional) – List containing the name of unwanted columns. Defaults to ‘address.id’.

  • if_exists (str, optional) – Inherited from the method pd.DataFrame().to_sql() for more information see: https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.to_sql.html Defaults to ‘append’

  • database_str (str, optional) – Name of the database that you want to access or create Defaults to ‘taxfix-challenge’.

  • table_str (str, optional) – Name of the table that you want to create or append your data Defaults to ‘FAKER_API’.

request_data_as_df(desired_number_of_rows)

This function is in charge of getting data from the API: https://fakerapi.it/api/v1/ and return all the information as a raw pandas DataFrame.

Transform - Datamasking

class faker.transform.datamask.MaskColumn[source]

This class is a collection of operations for masking pandas Dataframes accordingly to the desired characteristics. Every method applies transformations at the record level

Parameters

df (pd.DataFrame) – Pandas DataFrame to be transformed

Methods:

after_a_character(list_of_columns, character)

This method mask the row only after a certain parsed character. For example, the row with the value 'foo@email.com' will be transformed into 'foo@*********'(9*).

before_a_character(list_of_columns, character)

This method mask the row only after a certain parsed character. For example, the row with the value 'foo@email.com' will be transformed into '**@email.com'(3) :param list_of_columns: List of the columns to apply the function :type list_of_columns: List :param character: String with the character that will be used as reference to apply the method :type character: str.

by_len(list_of_columns)

This method mask the row accordingly with its length. For example, the record with the string 'foo' will return '***'.

keep_first(list_of_columns[, length])

This method masks the row by keeping a certain number of characters

keep_last(list_of_columns[, length])

This method masks the row by keeping a certain number of characters
after_a_character(list_of_columns: List, character: str)[source]

This method mask the row only after a certain parsed character. For example, the row with the value ‘foo@email.com’

will be transformed into ‘foo@*********’(9*)

Parameters

  • list_of_columns (List) – List of the columns to apply the function

  • character (str) – String with the character that will be used as reference to apply the method

keep_first(list_of_columns: List, length: int = 4)[source]
This method masks the row by keeping a certain number of characters

at the beginning of the string and replacing the others with ‘*’.

For example, the word ‘taxfix’ will be transformed into ‘taxf**’(4*) But the number of characters can be changed accordingly to the user’s choice. For example, if the user specifies length=2 then ‘taxfix’ will be

transformed into ‘ta****’ insted of ‘taxf**’

Parameters

  • list_of_columns (List) – List of the columns to apply the function

  • length (int, optional) – Number of characters that you want to keep Default to 4.

Returns

Pandas DataFrame with the transformed columns

Return type

df

keep_last(list_of_columns: List, length: int = 4)[source]
This method masks the row by keeping a certain number of characters

at the end of the string and replacing the others with ‘*’.

For example, the word ‘taxfix’ will be transformed into ‘**xfix’(4*) But the number of characters can be changed accordingly to the user’s choice. For example, if the user specifies length=2 then ‘taxfix’ will be

transformed into ‘****ix’ insted of ‘**xfix’

Parameters

  • list_of_columns (List) – List of the columns to apply the function

  • length (int, optional) – Number of characters that you want to keep Default to 4.

Returns

Pandas DataFrame with the transformed columns

Return type

df

Transform - Date

Functions:

convert_age_to_age_groups(df, column[, ...])

This function is in charge of dividing an age column into categories of '10 years age group' (i.e someone with 31 years old must be categorized in [30-40] age group category).

convert_birthday_to_age(df, column[, ...])

This function is in charge of converting a birthday column into a column with the age :param df: pandas dataframe that will be transformed :type df: pd.DataFrame :param column: name of the birthday column :type column: str
faker.transform.date.convert_age_to_age_groups()[source]

This function is in charge of dividing an age column into categories of ‘10 years age group’ (i.e someone with 31 years old must be categorized in [30-40] age group category).

Parameters

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – pandas dataframe that will be transformed

  • column (str) – name of the age column

  • keep_age_column (bool) – Set this parameter to True if you want to keep the column used in this transformation

Returns

Dataframe with the “age_group” column

Return type

df(pd.DataFrame)

faker.transform.date.convert_birthday_to_age()[source]

This function is in charge of converting a birthday column into a column with the age :param df: pandas dataframe that will be transformed :type df: pd.DataFrame :param column: name of the birthday column :type column: str

Returns

Dataframe with the “age” column

Return type

df(pd.DataFrame)

Load - Ingestion

Functions:

write_df_to_database(df, engine_str, table_str)

Write your pandas DataFrame into a database using supported SQLAlchemy connectors.
faker.load.ingestion.write_df_to_database(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, engine_str: str, table_str: str, if_exists: str = 'append') → None[source]

Write your pandas DataFrame into a database using supported SQLAlchemy connectors.

Parameters

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – Pandas DataFrame that you want to insert into your database

  • engine_str (str) – String containing SQLAlchemy format connection

  • table_str (str) – Name of the table that you want to append data or create

  • if_exists (str, optional) – Inherited from the method pd.DataFrame().to_sql() for more information see: https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.to_sql.html Defaults to ‘append’
